oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Irving D. Sutton Meat Market
oai_dc:dc.dc:description:
A photogragh, an advertisement and a newspaper clipping pertaining to Irving Sutton's Market at 54/56 Main St., in New Paltz, NY.

Irving Sutton, born in 1869, was the son of Thomas Sutton and Gertrude Freer Sutton, and a lifelong resident of New Paltz. Irving went into business with his father in 1884 and built the building presently (2007) standing in 1888. The basement of the building was used as the butcher shop and the Sutton family lived on the second and third floors. Sutton kept his business operating for more than 62 years, and was known as the oldest merchant in New Paltz.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: DeWitt, Tjeryck (1762-1822)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This letter, from a son to his father is conveying news of a surprise armed attack, under the command of General Scott, on an assembly of Native Americans that tragically culminated in their demise. The author interprets the massacre of the Native Americans in the language of triumph and victory, validated by the grisly act of scalping hundreds of victims

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Sarah Elizabeth Watkins Elting
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Studio portrait of Sarah Elizabeth Watkins Elting. Ms. Elting is wearing dress reformers attire, which includes a three quarter length dress with matching pants. Sarah Elting is standing in front of a backdrop of a stairway in a photographic studio. She is leaning against a pedestal with a large pine cone on top. She is holding a stick or horse crop and is wearing thick gloves. She appears to have a large dark cloth in her hand. Sarah married Luther Hasbrouck in 1853 and had three children, only one son living past infancy. She was educated at the Goshen institute and became the principal of the Middletown Female Institute at the age of 18. She was later appointed at Rutgers Female Institute in New York City. She left her position at the Institute to marry Luther Hasbrouck in 1853. In the course of her married life she traveled with her husband and surviving son, Irving, throughout the United States and Europe. Sarah died in 1899 in Poughkeepsie, NY.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Fire at the Old Normal School
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The fire at the Old New Paltz Normal School. The fire took place on the evening of April 17th, 1906. John C. Haines wrote the following in his journal: "At 5 minutes of 12 tonight I winked the lights as a signet that I would shut down at 12 Oclock and after I had winked the lights Mr Johnston called me up on the telephone and said I must keep the Plant running for there was a fire in the Village and I ran and there [was] some coal on the furnace and Mel Warmeller ran in the Plant and told me to blow the whistle for the Normal School was on fire. It burned until daylight. They got a few things out of the building but everything else was burned. Great crowds from the Surrounding county flocked to the scene of the fire today” – John Haines worked in the village electric plant. The New Paltz Diary of John C. Haines 1906-1907 can be found at the Havialnd-Heidgerd Historic Collection at the Elting Library in New Paltz.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Jean Hasbrouck house
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Twenty men, women and children posed in front of the Jean Hasbrouck House in New Paltz. The man standing on the stoop, hat in hand, is most probably Albert Donaldson. Donaldson and his family rented the house some time after 1886 until 1910. Donaldson, was a teamster who had a successful business transporting tourists and goods to and from the New Paltz train station to the Mohonk Mountain House. Donaldson stabled his horses and wagons in the barns on the property. According to the 1900 Federal Census, Donaldson was 32, his wife Josephine, 33, one son Charles, aged between 11 and 13 and a daughter, Hazel, who was 8 years old.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Letter written by Johannes Lefevre to his brother Peter during his Junior year at Union College in Schenectady, NY. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Court of sessions, September 3, 1707
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Isaac Hasbrouck of New Paltz was accused of assaulting Hugo Freer. He beat, wounded, and bruised Hugo Freer so that his ear bled. Hasbrouck pleaded guilty and threw himself upon the Court. He was ordered to pay 20 shillings. During the same session a slave named Pierro from the Town of Rochester in Ulster County was accused of a similar crime, assaulting Catrina Cortregt. He plead guilty and threw himself upon the court. The court ordered that he be publicly whipped ten times upon the naked back at every corner of the Town of Kingston. He was also ordered to pay all costs and to remain in custody until the costs could be paid.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Melon story
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: C. H. Gallup (Poughkeepsie, N.Y.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Advertisement for C. H. Gallup & Co., a commercial photographic portrait studio in Poughkeepsie, NY. The before-and-after scene on the recto shows three black boys caught stealing watermelon from a white farmer. The verso contains an extended inscription describing the expressions on the boys' faces; makes a connection between the racist stereotype of the "darkies and the melon" and Gallup's production of "natural" and "happy" expressions in his studio.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: New Paltz Register of Slaves (1799-1825)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Register of Slaves (1799-1825) was kept by the Town Clerk of New Paltz as a requirement of the New York State Manumission Act of 1799. In keeping the slave register, the town clerk recorded the births of children born to slaves owned by the town's inhabitants. Each entry includes the owner's name, the slave's name, sex, and date of birth. In addition, located in the final pages of the book is an entry entitled the "Record of Disbandments", which list the dates that the slave owners freed, or "abandoned" individual slave children in accordance with the 1799 act.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Kingston Slave Conspiracy
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "Negro Plot in Ulster County". An account of a slave conspiracy uncovered by John Schoonmaker. Schoonmaker overheard one of his slaves, York, talking to one of Johannes Schoonmaker's slaves, Joe, about a plan to set the houses of their masters on fire and kill the people as they ran out. Several other slaves in the area were to take part in the plan. Their motive was freedom from slavery.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: 1810-09-05, Society of negroes unsettled
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In 1810 a group of New Paltz slave holders joined together to form "The Society of Negroes Unsettled". This group of twelve men appointed four among them to search for slaves that had run away from the group. They were to be paid $14 a day for travel within sixty miles from home and $16 a day for travel further than sixty miles from home. It was also agreed that every slave owner would reward the captor a sum of thirty dollars when the slave was delivered to his or her master or brought to the Ulster County jail. Each subscriber was also asked for an advance of $5.00 to be paid to the bounty hunters about to embark on the search.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Special court held in Kingston, NY in January 1696. Thom, a slave of Peter Crispel, was accused of murdering a negro woman. He was sentenced to be hanged by the neck, have his throat cut with a knife, and then hanged in a chain as an example to others.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: An act to incourage the baptizing of Negro, Indian and Mulatto slaves
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Law passed October 21, 1706 stating that slaves may be baptized, but that baptizing them is not a reason to set them free. The law also states that children born to slaves are also slaves, and that no slave may testify for or against a freeman in court.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Rev. Particular, Synod of Albany concerning "The Memorial of Ann Bevier and Rachel Westbrook, members of the Reformed Protestant Dutch Church of Rochester"
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Rachel Westbrook and Ann Bevier, members of the Reformed Dutch Church of Rochester have written to the Synod in Albany requesting their help in deciding the fate of their minister, the Reverend James Murphy. The two women, along with help from some other members of the congregation, have found evidence that Murphy has been hiding his true ancestry. This document includes affidavits as well as other supporting documents used to condemn the minister.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: An act to prevent the runing away of slaves out of the City and County of Albany to the French at Cannada
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Law passed May 14, 1745 to prevent slaves from running away to Canada and passing information to the French during King George's War (one of the French and Indian Wars). Any slave convicted of trying to escape to Canada would be put to death. The owners of slaves executed under this law would be compensated up to 35 pounds for their loss. This law was to expire at the end of the war with France.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Bounty hunters agreement
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Articles of agreement: Jacob J. Hasbrouck and Isaiah Hasbrouck agreed to Josiah Eltinge, William Hasbrouck, Philip Dayo, and Andries Lefever Jr. that if they found any of the runaway slaves listed "they may sell and dispose of the said negroes." They were to be paid a percentage of the amount the slave was sold for, returning the remainder to the owner of the said slave. They also agreed that if they did not find any of the runaways, they would not charge for their trouble, time, or expense.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Law passed February 22, 1788 stating that every Negro, Mulatto or Mestee who was a slave at the time this law was passed shall be a slave for his or her life unless manumitted or set free. The law also states that the children of Negro, Mulatto, or Mestee slave women were also slaves.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Judy Jackson obituary
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Obituary of Judy Jackson, often called Aunt Judy. The obituary briefly describes her life as a slave. She was two years old when Jeremiah Merrit bought her and her mother. Judy was later purchased by Philip LeFevre as a wedding gift for his son, Andries. She remained a slave of Andries until 1827 when slaves in New York were set free. She died at age 98.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: New Paltz Independent
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Newspaper article about James Thomas' trip to Maryland, where he had escaped from slavery 35 years earlier. James initially ran away to Canada, later settling in Ohioville, NY. He did not tell his neighbors that he was a slave until the emancipation proclamation set all the slaves free. He visited his 85 year old mother and went to Washington D.C. during this trip.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: An act to prevent aged and decrepit slaves from becoming burthensome within this colony
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Law passed March 8, 1773 stating that slave owners who knowingly allow their slaves to beg of others are subject to a fine of 10 pounds per offence. The law also states that slave owners who knowingly sell a slave that can no longer work are subject to a fine of 20 pounds and that such sales will be considered void.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: An act to prevent the firing of guns and other fire arms within this colony
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Law passed March 8, 1773 that made it illegal to fire guns from December 31 to January 2. If a white person is found guilty of breaking this law he or she would have to pay a fine of 20 shillings or serve 1 month in jail. If a slave is found guilty of breaking this law he or she will be subject to a public whipping of up to 39 lashes.
